verses.text: Bezalel made the ark of acacia wood. Its length was two and a half cubits, its width one and a half cubits, and its height one and a half cubits.
verses.comment: A cubit is roughly 18 inches or 45 centimeters. See note at Ex. 25:10.

verses.text: And he overlaid it with pure gold inside and outside, and made a molding of gold around it.
verses.comment: Translated 'molding' to convey 'zer,' the gold border/lip.

verses.text: He cast four rings of gold for it on its four feet, two rings on one side, and two rings on the other side.
verses.comment: Maintains the original description of the rings’ positions.

verses.text: And he made poles of acacia wood and overlaid them with gold.
verses.comment: No significant difference from the original.

verses.text: He put the poles into the rings on the sides of the ark, to carry the ark.
verses.comment: Clear, direct translation for readability.

verses.text: And he made a mercy seat of pure gold, two and a half cubits long and one and a half cubits wide.
verses.comment: ‘Mercy seat’ translates Hebrew ‘kapporet,’ the gold lid covering the ark.

verses.text: He made two cherubim of hammered gold. He made them at the two ends of the mercy seat.
verses.comment: ‘Cherubim’ kept in transliteration, consistent with standard convention.

verses.text: One cherub at one end and one cherub at the other end. He made the cherubim at the two ends of one piece with the mercy seat.
verses.comment: Phrase ‘of one piece’ clarifies the construction as a single unit.

verses.text: The cherubim spread out their wings above, overshadowing the mercy seat with their wings. They faced each other. The faces of the cherubim were turned toward the mercy seat.
verses.comment: ‘Overshadowing’ matches Hebrew ‘sakakh,’ meaning to cover or protect.

verses.text: He made the table of acacia wood, two cubits long, one cubit wide, and one and a half cubits high.
verses.comment: Table dimensions in cubits, as in original.

verses.text: He overlaid it with pure gold and made a molding of gold around it.
verses.comment: ‘Molding’ for the gold lip/border.

verses.text: He made a rim a handbreadth wide around it, and made a gold molding for the rim around it.
verses.comment: ‘Handbreadth’ is about 3–4 inches or 8–10 centimeters. Used to match the original.

verses.text: He cast four rings of gold for it and put the rings on the four corners that were at its four legs.
verses.comment: ‘Corners’ translated directly from Hebrew.

verses.text: The rings were close to the frame, as holders for the poles to carry the table.
verses.comment: Clarifies function and placement of rings.

verses.text: He made the poles of acacia wood to carry the table, and overlaid them with gold.
verses.comment: Faithfully rendered from Hebrew.

verses.text: And he made the vessels which were on the table—its plates and dishes and bowls, and flagons with which to pour—of pure gold.
verses.comment: ‘Flagons’ renders ‘qammonim’—utensils for pouring.

verses.text: He made the lampstand of pure gold. He made the lampstand of hammered work, its base, its shaft, its cups, its calyxes, and its flowers were of one piece with it.
verses.comment: ‘Calyxes’ refers to decorative features beneath or around the lamp cups.

verses.text: There were six branches going out of its sides, three branches of the lampstand out of one side of it and three branches out of the other side.
verses.comment: Faithful to Hebrew, clarifying sides and number of branches.

verses.text: Three cups shaped like almond blossoms in one branch, with calyx and flower; and three cups made like almond blossoms in the next branch, with calyx and flower—so for the six branches going out of the lampstand.
verses.comment: Explains ‘cups shaped like almond blossoms,’ as in original.

verses.text: On the lampstand itself were four cups made like almond blossoms, with calyxes and flowers.

And a calyx was under the first pair of branches of the same, another calyx under the second pair of branches of the same, and a calyx under the third pair of branches of the same, for the six branches going out of it.
verses.comment: Clarifies Hebrew word order about calyx placement.

verses.text: Their calyxes and their branches were of one piece with it. The whole of it was one hammered work of pure gold.
verses.comment: Emphasizes single-piece construction.

verses.text: He made its seven lamps and its tongs and its trays of pure gold.
verses.comment: ‘Tongs’ and ‘trays’ refer to maintenance tools for the lampstand.

verses.text: He made it and all its utensils out of a talent of pure gold.
verses.comment: A ‘talent’ is about 75 pounds or 34 kilograms.

verses.text: He made the altar of incense of acacia wood. Its length was a cubit, its width a cubit—it was square—and its height was two cubits. Its horns were of one piece with it.
verses.comment: ‘Horns’ on altar: raised corners, common in ancient altars.

verses.text: He overlaid it with pure gold, its top, its sides all around, and its horns. He made a molding of gold around it.
He made two rings of gold for it under its molding, on two opposite sides, as holders for the poles with which to carry it.
He made the poles of acacia wood, and overlaid them with gold.
He made the holy anointing oil also, and the pure fragrant incense, blended as by the perfumer.
verses.comment: ‘Blended as by the perfumer’ reflects the special, skilled mixing required (see also Ex 30).
